segments.text: He said that you're alienating them?
Yeah, he said, you people are alienating a lot of whites in this area.
And I asked him why, and he said, well, because you're being too pushy to further the cause of these Hispanics attending college and all that.
And then when I told him that the majority of these recipients were Anglos, not Hispanics,
He was very surprised to know this.
He thought that we existed only for the benefit and the enhancement of the Hispanic culture.
That's not so.
Then did he donate something?
Then he said, I'm going to give you a donation out of my pocket.
Ten dollars.
He said, well I cannot be present at your dance.
As you know, or you probably don't know, because the Black and White Ball Association is an organization that never has sought publicity.
It works in a very low key profile.
And last year, their annual dance is held in February.
And the Bolo Brazos, now defeated,
and his candidacy for re-election was a guest of honor.
The year before then, Phil Grand was our guest of honor.
And both last year and the year before then, President Miller has attended on both occasions.
How many do you usually have turn on at the dance?
in the vicinity of 250, something like that.
I neglected to tell you the most productive source of income, and that is the Ugly King contest.
Oh yeah, I was reading about that.
See, the Black and White Ball Association invites certain prominent members of the community
to be candidates for ugly king with the idea that the one who collects the most votes will become king and be crowned king at the dance.
Well, each vote counts, each vote costs one penny.
And 1978, a local practitioner
local physician here by the name of Shipman was crowned king.
He collected by himself sixteen hundred dollars.
Commissioner Cooley who was county commissioner for precinct one and I and uh and Andy Herrera were all uh candidates and uh Andy

and his followers contributed about twelve hundred dollars to his campaign and see all of that goes for the payment of for for the award of scholarship there isn't a single penny out of that ugly king contest that is spent for anything else so you see all told now see uh Dr. Shipman collected sixteen hundred
and Andy about $1,200, and Bill Cooley and I brought in about seven or eight hundred dollars apiece.
And so that was a very significant sum of money, all of which was used for scholarships.
I have a question.
it deals with early period of your life when when you left and went into the Marine Corps why did you decide to come back to A&M if you felt you were being discriminated against?
I think it's the best school in the country.
There are a lot of other schools that you could have gone to.
And another thing is I'm a resident of Texas.
It has the only College of Veterinary Medicine in it.
You know, it made no sense for me to try and get a degree in veterinary medicine outside of my state.
So all of the reasons were very prominent in my decision.
How could you tell me about your military career?
Sure.
I was commissioned in the ROTC here in 1951.
And then I was called to active duty in 1952, only a few months after I had graduated.
This is before you went on to California?
No.
I went to California to practice with Dr. Tully there in North Hollywood, California.
I still have my California license, as you can see up there.
And I was called to active duty in November of 1952.
So just a few months after you were out in California?
Yeah, I had just gotten out of school in May.
You see, I thought that it was a mistake, you know, that I shouldn't be called because I had already served in World War II.
And at that time, 1952, they were calling people for the Korean emergency.
who had never served before.
And I think the top priorities was, the top priority was the people who had been in the A.H.D.P.
program, had had their education paid for, and had never returned Uncle Sam the favor.
You see?
But, I was, I was recalled to active duty anyway, and I went.
And when I reached
The meat and dairy hygiene school in Chicago, I was the only veteran in the class.
All the rest of them were ASTP boys.
They'd never seen one day's active duty, you see.
They were all veterinarians, of course.
We were all veterinarians.
Were you called into the Army or the Marines?
No, the Army.
The Marines never did have any veterinarians.
I was called into the Army.
I was commissioned here in the Army, and so they said,
We need you for this emergency."
And I'm going to tell you my opinion.
When I got to Chicago, they said, well, we don't understand here why you should have been called.
I said, I've been complaining about this for the last three months.
I told them I was a veteran, served two years in the Marines, served abroad.
They said, well, this is obviously a mistake because none of these other guys is a veteran.

But nonetheless, I went through a meeting there at Hygiene School, was assigned to Fort Sam, and I was so anxious to get out of the Army, to return to my practice of veterinary medicine, that the first day that I became eligible to get out, I did.
I got out after serving only 15 months.
And I went back into practice, and this time I practiced in El Paso.
Why didn't you go back to California?
I didn't go back to California because the job that I left there had already been filled by somebody else.
I got out in February, which is a very poor month, to try and get a job with an older practitioner.
And that same job that I left was out.
I couldn't return to it.
But I began to correspond with an older gentleman
who lived in Chino, and he gave me the opportunity to become a 50% partner in California.

And I was considering very seriously going to work for him, but I was offered a job in El Paso by a practitioner for whom I had worked as a student during my sophomore and junior years, and during my junior and senior year.
And he offered me a contract, which I accepted, and I went to work there instead.
Well, it turned out that he had set up a probationary period of six months.
And when five months were up, I asked him, let's sign the contract, you know.
And he said, well, I've been to my lawyers, and my lawyers tell me that I offered you too much in that original contract.
Here is an alternate contract."
And I said, I don't even want to look at it, because you and I agreed that you were going to give me this contract, and I will accept nothing else.
He said, well, I'm sorry, I can't give you that.
And I said, well, in that case, I won't.
I feel then that you have broken your word, and I feel no moral obligation or commitment to you.
And so,
Uh, it was during this interval that I received a call from the dean of the College of Veterinary Medicine here by the name of Armstead.
And he said, uh, would you like to come and teach here?
Really?
Yeah.
Had you been corresponding with him?
No, no, no, but you see I had been an outstanding student here.
He was my teacher.
Oh, really?
And so he called me and said... How did he even know where you lived?
Former student's directory or something?
No, he knew where I was because we had corresponded.
I never asked him for a job, but out of the clear blue sky, I get this call from Armstead and he said, I've got a job open.
I've got an opening in the small animal clinic here.
Would you consider an institutional career, an academic career?
And I told him I'd never considered an academic career.
He said, well, I'll give you a week to think about it.
I'll pay you more than you're getting now and give you a chance to work on a master's.
And before the week was up, I made up my mind to come to A&M as a teacher.
I came here in 1954.
And I began to teach here, and in 1957, I got the Outstanding Teacher Award from the College of Veterinary Medicine.
I published more papers than anybody else in my department did.
I was very happy here, teaching the small animal clinic, but during the five years that I stayed here, I never got a single raise.
From 54 to 57?
From 54 to 59.
Oh, okay, okay.
See?
During those five years.
Why not?
You answer the question.
I don't know why not.
I mean, what else does a man have to do to demonstrate his competency?
There have been people here teaching for 30 years who have never gotten that award, and I got it in three.
Plus you had a number of publications.
I was the one that published the most.
And in my own department, see, at that time the small animal clinic and the large animal clinic were in the Department of Veterinary Medicine and Surgery.
I was the only one in my department who had an advanced degree in my specialty.
I got that degree.
You got your master's degree.
I got a master's degree in veterinary medicine and surgery when not even the head of my department had a master's degree in veterinary medicine and surgery.
There were two other people in that department who had master's degrees, but they were not in veterinary medicine and surgery.
One of them in microbiology and one in anatomy.
I didn't know how else I could demonstrate.
And you never got a raise for five years?
I didn't get a single raise.
I was still an instructor at the end of five years.
The same rank that I had obtained when I came here.
My pay Did he take this to the dean?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
What did he say?
Well, he said, if you promise to stay here another year, you'll be number one on the list for promotion.
And I thought, well, I wasn't going to stick around here.
So I made an application.
How much were you being paid?
You were going to say that.
That was my total pay.
That was the highest pay that I attained at A&M during those five years.
That's what it was when you started and that's what it was when you ended.
Well, when I started, except for the periodic cost of living increase.
Oh, so they gave you a cost of living increase.
Yeah.
But they never gave you a promotion.
They never gave me a promotion or they never gave me any...
any increase in pay due to demonstrated achievements or competence.
No merit raising?
No merit raising.
Were other colleagues of yours getting merit raises?
Oh yeah, sure.
As a matter of fact, we were hiring people that were working for me that were getting more money than I was.
You know, at that time, there were two clinicians in the small animal clinic.

That was Dr. Beamer and myself, and we hired a guy from Cornell who stayed here only a few months and left, and then we hired a fellow who was working on a master's here, and he was making more money than I.
Then he left, and then we hired Dr. Ellett.
who was the one that ascended to the directorship of the Small Animal Clinic after Beamer died and after I had left.
But I applied for active duty with the Army on two conditions.
Oh, in 1959 then?
Okay, so by 1959 you were...
Oh yeah, I was discouraged.
And during that interval you had received a master's degree from A&M?
Yes.
Okay, and then in 1959 you decided to apply for active duty in the Army again.
That's right.
Okay, and you tell me about that.
And what were those conditions?
Those conditions were, number one, that I be sent to the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology.
to be trained as a pathologist.
And number two, that I be promoted to captain immediately.
I was the first lieutenant in the reserves.
And those two conditions were met by the Army.
They called me out of civilian life to go fill a job, a job for which I had to compete with people who were on active duty.
They yanked me out of civilian life and put me in Washington at the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology, and they began to train me as a pathologist.
And they sent me to Japan, where I was the chief of the Department of Veterinary Laboratory Medicine over there.
And how long were you there in Japan?
I was three years.
Both of my kids were born in Japan.
There they are.
Then I was sent to Fort Knox.
And then from Fort Knox, I was sent to Michigan State University to get my PhD.
The Army sent you?
The Army sent me.
And I graduated first in my class.
And when was that?
In 1968, I got my PhD.
Why did they send you for advanced training?
Because I applied for it.
A circular was sent out to all the veterinary detachments and offering this opportunity for some officer to get a PhD in veterinary pathology.
That was the first instance in which they had made this offer in veterinary pathology.
So I jumped on it and I was a candidate and they considered my qualification and I was the one selected.
What a great opportunity.
You must have froze up there.
Oh my God, it was cold in Michigan.
But my wife is from there and she was close to her folks.
Is that where you met your wife?
No, you must have met your wife long before that.
No, I met my wife in Washington, D.C.
I met her while I was attending the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology as a trainee.
I graduated from Michigan State with a PhD in 1968.
In that same year, I became a board-certified pathologist, you see.
There's only about 400 of us in the world.
And then following that, I went to Fort Detrick, where I was chief of pathology there, and then chief of pathology at the medical research laboratory in Fitzsimmons.
And in due time, I made my regular promotions.
And finally, in 1973, I was promoted to full colonel.
At that time, the United States Department of Agriculture sent a request to the Surgeon General to have a veterinarian assigned to them to develop a national plan
by which this country could deploy military resources to the control of a foreign animal disease that might have gained introduction into this country.
And so I worked up this national plan, and it became an Army regulation.
And for this, I was given that award.
The USDA gave me that award.
Oh, wow.
How nice.
1976, and then did you resign after that?
Well, I retired.
Oh, you retired in the Army?
Yeah.
So then you had how many years in?
At that time I was credited with 28 years of military service.
I also was given an A prefix in pathology by the Surgeon General, which means that you have attained the highest competence in your field.
Really?
There's that letter in 1975.
and I got the Legion of Merit and a Certificate of Achievement from the Surgeon General for the work that I did in pathology.
Well, after that, why did you ever decide to come back here?
Well, in 1974, when I was still on active duty, this university was looking for somebody to head up an Institute of Tropical Veterinary Medicine.
which had been established in 1966 and supported entirely by federal funds and whatever contracts could be generated by this institute.
And because of my experience in foreign animal disease control and the fact that I had traveled abroad
they offered me this job.
Dean Shelton offered me a job.

And I thought that I had always wanted to return to Texas, but I wanted to be in pathology in the specialty which brings me the greatest pleasure, and that is the study and control of foreign animal diseases.

And so this was a beautiful opportunity to take over this institute, but when I arrived here and we agreed what the salary would be and all that, I was given a partial appointment in this department here because I am a pathologist.
So you had a joint appointment then?
Yes.
One as director?
Director of the institute and a full professor of pathology.
I see.
So I accepted the job only to find out after I arrived here that there was not going to be a nickel support from the state of Texas.
From the directorship?
From the support of the activities of the Institute.
Oh, okay, for the Institute?
Yeah, for the Institute.
So that had to be funded totally by federal monies?
By federal monies and also whatever
contracts we were able to generate from pharmaceutical companies or etc.
And that displeased me very much.
Or grants.
Yes.
Or, you know, somebody that might want to make a philanthropic organization to, donation to.
That displeased me very much and I began to try and convince the people here that
the Institute could not possibly exist unless it was supported by the state of Texas.
Because the golden age during which the Agency for International Development was awarding monies right and left was over.
And so I felt that the core support should come from the state of Texas.
That is to say, the payment of salaries to my professionals,
and to my technicians and to support the research that we were doing, see.
And wherever I went I hit a stone wall, see, and no one supported us with one nickel during thirteen years that the institute was in existence.
We were able to establish for the university three laboratories
One in Falcon Heights.
It's an air-conditioned building paid for by federal funds.
One that is on the third floor of this building.
It's an arthropod tissue culture lab that the institute, under my direction, instituted.
And the third one was a histopathology laboratory, again without any state support.
installed and still in existence.
All three of these are going businesses.
Well in 1979 my disenchantment was complete and I resigned as director of the Institute and the Institute of Tropical Veterinary Medicine has since become defunct.
Really?
With three labs?
Yes.
Now what do those labs do?
There has been another, you might say, agency of the College of Veterinary Medicine created, which they call the Center for Tropical Animal Health.
It has no director, per se.
And so they and the Department of Entomology are jointly using the facilities at Falcon
And they're using the arthropod tissue culture lab here out of microbiology, which is supporting the salary of the persons who are now running it.
And the histopathology lab is supported by the Department of Anatomy and partially by microbiology.
So how many people did you have on your staff at the institute?
Well... And what type of research did you do?
Our research was devoted almost entirely

to the control of anaplasmosis and babesiosis, which are two diseases of cattle, one of which is present in the state of Texas, and the other one is Texas fever, which at one time was a scourge of the South, and it's present in Mexico, it's present in all the Caribbean countries, and also in Central and South America, and poses a real threat
I think, of the bovine industries of this state.
We were trying to develop vaccines against these two.
So our research was oriented entirely towards those two diseases because the Institute does not have a biologically secure area in which we can study viral diseases, for example.
We don't have a
never did have a biologically secure wing that was permitted to expand the scope of her research.
But in this resignation, there was an implicit understanding that I would join this department full-time and assume
teaching responsibilities that I had not heretofore had had because of the administrative functions of the director.
So I'm now teaching three courses in this department.
And that's where it's at.
Well, tell me about, let's get back to the Institute for a minute.
How many staff members did you have?
How big of an operation was this?
All right, it was a very big operation.
During the time that it existed, it brought to this campus over four and a half million dollars.

We had an associate director for research and an associate director for international activities whose function it was to seek out sources of money and to write proposals and compete with other agencies who were after the federal dollar.
Uh, so to answer your question, at one time we had about uh, about seven or eight veterinarians.
Oh yeah.
Who were part-time here and part-time at the Institute?
There were, no, all of these people, except for two, well three, including me,
were on campus and supported by these federal monies.
And as a matter of fact, we paid the salaries of the people that served for the Institute in Columbia, South America.
There we had four veterinarians.
And then we were awarded a contract to work in Africa.
And the people that we deployed out of the Institute was a veterinarian,
a girl who finished in the class of 76.
And with these federal funds, we were paying these people.
That contract alone was over a million and a half dollars.
As a matter of fact, that contract is still going on in Mali.
That's in Mali?
In Mali.
And it was the Institute of Tropical Veterinary Medicine in conjunction with the Entomology Department
who jointly were supposed to help Mali seek out ways to eradicate the setzi fly and trypanosomiasis.

Trypanosomiasis being the most important African disease from a standpoint of the number of cattle that it kills and from an economic standpoint it is it continues to be the number one problem in Africa.
Now that contract is still
operating, and the people that originally were hired continue to be paid out of the federal monies.
My salary now is paid by the Department of Pathology.
I have nothing to do anymore with the Institute of Tropical Veteran Medicine, which in the first place does not exist anymore.
And number two, with the foreign animal disease programs, I have had to leave that
on the back burner.
Well, what about the research in the institute and at this university?
Is it much more international in flavor, do you think, over the past years, or has it changed in any way since the 50s when you were here, then when you came back?
Well, uh, this is only my opinion.
Sure, fine.
I think that the
If any criticism were directed against this College of Animal Medicine for any reason, it would have to be in the area of research.
I believe that we have some very competent researchers here, but there's just a very few of them that are in research.
And I think that our research capabilities could be greatly expanded

if the people of this college of veterinary medicine were permitted to and encouraged to develop and participate in programs of disease research that were not necessarily perfectly aligned with diseases that occurred.
